physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Neurological examination was nondiagnostic; brain MR imaging revealed a mesencephalic A VM with dilation of the vein of Galen.
Cerebral angiography confirmed the presence of a large mesencephalic A VM (Spetzlerâ€“Martin Grade 4) supplied by two posterior cerebral artery feeding branches with drainage into the vein of Galen.
Abdominal ultrasonography revealed the presence of a patent ductus venosus (PDV); there was no evidence of coagulopathy on laboratory examination.
Patient underwent surgical ligation of the PDV; during occlusion testing, portal pressure increased without complications.
Cerebral MR imaging showed the disappearance of the A VM nidus.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Complete regression of the A VM noted.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Angiography studies confirmed complete regression of the A VM with a residual deep venous angioma.
